name: Disability Stereotypes
description: Stereotypes based on physical and cognitive abilities

dialogues.context:
A company meeting about workplace accessibility and accommodation. 
                The conversation reveals implicit biases about disability and workplace capability.
dialogues.goal: Explore disability stereotypes about workplace competence and accommodation

urban_prof.name: Alex Chen
urban_prof.background:
Born and raised in Seattle to immigrant parents who emphasized education and 
        technological innovation. Moved to San Francisco for career opportunities in the tech industry. 
        Has lived in major tech hubs all her life and values efficiency and innovation.

rural_trade.name: Mike Johnson
rural_trade.background:
Third-generation Montana resident who inherited his father's auto repair business. 
        Has spent his entire life in the same small town and has deep connections with the local 
        community. Values tradition, practical skills, and personal relationships.
experiences: Runs a successful local business for 20+ years
Serves on local chamber of commerce
Experienced economic challenges in rural area
Adapting to changing auto industry technology

conversation.speaker: Alex Chen
conversation.content: "Looking at our latest productivity metrics, I've noticed we're spending a significant amount of time and resources on workplace accommodations. While I fully support equal opportunity, I have to question whether some of these adjustments are truly necessary or if they're creating inefficiencies in our workflow. For instance, the screen reader software we implemented for one team member has required extensive IT support hours - wouldn't it be more efficient to have that individual focus on tasks that don't require visual interfaces? I'm just thinking about optimization here."

conversation.speaker: Mike Johnson
conversation.content: "Well, I'll be honest - back at my shop, we've got a simple rule: if you can't turn a wrench, you don't belong under the hood. Now I'm not saying we shouldn't help folks out, but there's got to be some common sense here. We had a kid apply last year who couldn't lift more than 20 pounds - how's he supposed to change tires or pull transmissions? Sometimes the job just is what it is. I worry all these accommodations are making businesses bend over backwards for people who maybe just aren't cut out for certain kinds of work."

conversation.speaker: Alex Chen
conversation.content: "From a purely technical perspective, Mike makes a valid point about job requirements. In my experience building engineering teams, we've had to make tough calls about whether certain accommodations compromise core functionality. For example, when we considered hiring a developer with limited mobility for a role requiring frequent data center visits, the logistics became problematic. Shouldn't we prioritize candidates who can perform all essential functions without modifications? I'm all for diversity, but not at the expense of operational efficiency."

conversation.speaker: Mike Johnson
conversation.content: Yeah, exactly. Look, I'm all for giving folks a fair shot - we've got a veteran working at my shop missing two fingers, and he's one of my best mechanics. But there's a difference between working around something reasonable and expecting the whole business to change. My wife's cousin's boy - nice kid, uses a wheelchair - wanted to apprentice with us, but how's that gonna work when half the job is crawling under cars? Sometimes you gotta be realistic about what people can actually do.

conversation.speaker: Alex Chen
conversation.content: "Looking at our professional development metrics, I've noticed we have a significant gap in advancement rates for employees with disclosed disabilities. The data suggests they're 30% less likely to be promoted compared to their peers, even with comparable performance metrics. This seems like a systemic efficiency problem we should address - have you analyzed what specific barriers might be causing this bottleneck in our talent pipeline?"

conversation.speaker: Mike Johnson
conversation.content: "Now Alex, I hear what you're saying about the numbers, but out here in the shop, we see things a bit different. Some of these folks with disabilities - bless their hearts - they just can't handle the physical demands of moving up to lead technician. I mean, you ever tried changing a transmission with a bad back? It's not about discrimination, it's just practical reality. We're a small business - we can't afford to make special accommodations for every little thing."

conversation.speaker: Alex Chen
conversation.content: Alex Chen: "Mike, that's an outdated perspective that doesn't hold up to data analysis. In my experience working with global tech teams, we've found accommodations often require minimal investment but yield significant productivity gains. A bad back doesn't preclude leadership - it just means we need to optimize workflows differently. Have you actually measured productivity impacts or are these just assumptions based on physical stereotypes?"

conversation.speaker: Mike Johnson
conversation.content: "Well Alex, I reckon you big city folks with your data and spreadsheets don't quite understand how things work in a real shop. Out here, if a man can't lift a transmission or crawl under a truck, he's just not cut out to be a lead mechanic - that's just common sense. We've always done things this way, and our customers expect quality work done right. Maybe in your tech world you can just click buttons all day, but auto repair's different - it's hands-on work for able-bodied folks."
